## Detection of Occult Metastases in Sentinel Lymph Nodes From Colon Cancer Patients by K-ras Mutation Peptide Nucleic Acid Clamp PCR

Satu Oltedal, MSc,* Bjørnar Gilje, MD,† Hartwig Kørner, MD, PhD,‡§ Ole Gunnar Aasprong, MD,¶ Kjersti Tjensvoll, PhD,* Reino Heikkila¨, MD, PhD,† Rune Smaaland, MD, PhD,*† and Oddmund Nordgård, PhD*†

Objective: To identify colon cancer patients with occult lymph node metastases.

Summary of Background Data: The prognostic value of regional lymph node (LN) metastases in colorectal cancer patients is well established. The disease recurrences nevertheless experienced by 20% to 30% of the LN negative patients suggest a potential for improvement in current LN diagnostics. We suspect that a subgroup of the patients that are LN negative by routine examination has occult LN metastases that are prognostically relevant.

Methods: To identify these patients we applied ex vivo sentinel lymph node (SLN) mapping to colon cancer patients and analyzed the SLNs by a sensitive peptide nucleic acid clamp PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assay for K-ras mutations, using these mutations as a surrogate marker for tumor cells.

Results: SLNs were identified in 158 (96%) of 164 prospectively recruited patients with localized colon cancer. Of the 158 patients with successful SLN mapping, 67 (42%) had K-ras mutations detected in their primary tumors. We analyzed the SLNs from these patients by peptide nucleic acid clamp PCR for K-ras mutations and found mutations in SLNs from 35 (52%) patients. At least one SLN from 14 (70%) of 20 patients with histologically proven regional LN metastases was positive for the K-ras mutation test. Interestingly, 21 (45%) of the 47 patients without known LN metastases had K-ras mutations detected in their SLNs.

Conclusions: Sensitive detection of K-ras mutations in SLNs from colon cancer patients indicates the presence of occult metastases with potential prognostic implications.

( Ann Surg 2010;251: 1087-1091)

T he presence of metastases in regional lymph nodes (LNs) is an important prognostic factor for patients with operable colon cancer. Depending on the T-stage and the extent of LN involvement, the 5-year cancer-specific survival among patients with LN metastases (stage III patients) has been found to be in the range 44% to 83%. 1,2 In comparison, patients without LN metastases (stage I-II patients) have a 5-year cancer-specific survival in the range 72% to 93%. 1,3 Stage III patients may achieve a relative survival benefit of about 30% if treated with

From the *Laboratory for Molecular Biology, Stavanger University Hospital, Stavanger, Norway; Departments of †Hematology and Oncology, and ‡Surgery, Stavanger University Hospital, Stavanger, Norway; §Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Bergen, Bergen, Norway; and ¶Department of Pathology, Stavanger University Hospital, Stavanger, Norway.

Reino Heikkilais currently at Roche Norge AS, Oslo, Norway.

Supported by Western Norway Regional Health Authorities, the Norwegian Cancer Society, and the Folke Hermansen Fund.

Reprints: Oddmund Nordgård, PhD, Laboratory for Molecular Biology, Stavanger University Hospital, PO Box 8100, N-4068 Stavanger, Norway. E-mail: nood@sus.no.

Copyright © 2010 by Lippincott Williams & Wilkins ISSN: 0003-4932/10/25106-1087

DOI: 10.1097/SLA.0b013e3181dae1bc

|

1087

adjuvant 5-fluorouracil in combination with levamisole or leucovorin. 2,4 A similar effect of adjuvant chemotherapy among stage II patients has been difficult to prove. 5-7 Subgroups of stage II patients with poor prognosis may still benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy, and risk factors, such as T4 tumors, bowel perforation, and low number of regional LNs examined, have been suggested to guide the treatment. 5,6,8 There is also reason to suspect that some of the patients, who are LN negative after examination by routine histology, have undetected LN micrometastases that may be relevant for prognosis and treatment response. 9

To ensure examination of the LNs most likely to contain metastases, the sentinel lymph node (SLN) mapping technique was established (reviewed in 10-12 ). The first LNs to receive afferent lymph drainage from the primary tumor are defined as SLNs. 13 They are identified by injection of a tracer dye and/or radioactive isotope near the tumor, either during surgery (in vivo) or after surgery (ex vivo). Because the number of SLNs is relatively low, it is possible to use more sensitive and resource demanding technology to analyze them. We have recently reported real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) based detection of metastases in SLNs identified ex vivo in the resection specimen from 131 patients undergoing curative surgery for colon cancer. 14 Despite the absence of LN involvement detected by routine histology, we observed elevated levels of the epithelial-specific cytokeratin 20 or mucin 2 mRNAs in SLNs in around 50% of N0 patients, indicating the presence of occult metastases.

Mutations in the K-ras gene are present in 30% to 50% of colorectal cancers. 15-18 The majority of these mutations are located in codons 12, 13, and 61 of the K-ras coding sequence. As these mutations are absent in normal LNs, their detection can be used as a surrogate marker for tumor cells in regional LNs from patients with mutated primary tumors. 19-22 We recently introduced an improved assay for detecting K-ras mutations in codons 12 and 13 by real-time peptide nucleic acid (PNA) clamp PCR. 23 Using a highfidelity DNA polymerase, we were able to increase the sensitivity for mutations 10-fold. Downregulation of epithelial-specific genes in tumors with low differentiation grade may reduce their potential as LN metastasis markers in this patient group. K-ras mutations as a tumor cell marker are not expected to suffer from the same problem, as a K-ras mutation is supposed to be present in all descendants of a tumor cell in which the mutation has occurred. 18,24 We here report the so far largest study of K-ras mutations used as metastasis markers in SLNs from operated colon cancer patients with K-ras mutations in their primary tumors.

## METHODS

## Patients

Consecutive patients undergoing elective surgery for verified or suspected colon cancer at Stavanger University Hospital were recruited between May 2003 and October 2008. The hospital is the only provider of surgical services to a population of 320,000. The

patients with noninvasive tumors (T0 and Tis; 22), evidence of distant metastases at the time of surgery, (27) missing tumor biopsies (1), or deviations from the SLN mapping procedure (2) were excluded. One patient treated with temporary colon stent preoperatively was also excluded. The included patients did not receive preoperative radiation- or chemotherapy. The regional ethical committee approved the study, and informed consents were obtained.

## SLN Mapping

Ex vivo SLN mapping was performed as previously described. 14 One half of each SLN was formalin-fixed for routine histology, and the other half was snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80°C for molecular analyses. Biopsies of 20 to 50 mm 3 were taken fresh from the outer rim of the tumors short time after resection ( < 2 hours), snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80°C. Routine HES (hematoxylin, eosin, and safranin) staining was performed as previously described. 14

## Cell Line Culturing

The human colon adenocarcinoma cell line LS174T was purchased from the European Collection of Cell Cultures (Salisbury, United Kingdom) and cultured according to the recommendations of the manufacturer.

## DNA Isolation From Tissue, Blood, and Cell Lines

Tumor biopsies and bisected SLNs were transferred frozen to RLT lysis buffer (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) and homogenized immediately with an Ultra-Turrax T8 (IKA Works, Staufen, Germany) rotor-stator homogenizer. DNA from tissue was isolated by a combination of the RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) and the DNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) for the first 129 patients and with the Allprep DNA/ RNA isolation kit (Qiagen) for the last 35 patients to allow the isolation of both RNA and DNA from the same samples. DNA from the LS174T cell line was isolated with the same combination of the RNeasy Mini kit and the DNeasy Mini kit, whereas DNA from blood was isolated with a combination of the RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) and the DNeasy Blood and Tissue kit (Qiagen). DNA concentrations were determined by ultraviolet (260 nm) spectrophotometry.

## Primers and Peptide Nucleic Acid

The sequences of the PCR primers employed in the PNA clamp real-time PCR assay were 5 ' -GCCTGCTGAAAATGACTGAATATAA-3 ' (forward) and 5 ' -CGTCAAGGCACTCTTGCCTAC-3 ' (reverse). The PNA sequence was 5 ' -CCTACGCCACCAGCTCC-3 ' .

## PNA Clamp PCR

Phusion HS-based PNA clamp PCR was performed in an Mx3000P real-time PCR instrument (Stratagene) as previously described. 23 The amount of template in each reaction was 200 ng. Each sample was analyzed in triplicates both with and without PNA. Negative and positive controls were included in every run. Wild-type DNA was used as a negative control, whereas the positive control was a 1:1000 dilution of DNA from the colorectal carcinoma cell line LS174T (heterozygous GGT > GAT codon 12 K-ras mutation [ c.35G > A ] )in wild-type DNA. For each sample we computed.

𝚫 Ct = Ct + PNA -Ct -PNA

where Ct + PNA and Ct -PNA denoted the Ct -values for the mean amplification curves (triplicates) of the reactions with PNA and without PNA, respectively. By this approach, the relative 𝚫 Ct parameter was normalized against both DNA amount and quality ( -PNA). To obtain a more easily interpreted parameter, we computed.

𝚫𝚫 Ct =𝚫 Ct wt,min -𝚫 Ct sample

1088 | www.annalsofsurgery.com

where 𝚫 Ct wt,min ( = 15.15) denoted the lowest 𝚫 Ct measured for the wild-type control included in every run. A sample was defined as positive for K-ras mutations when 𝚫𝚫 Ct > 0, which means that the 𝚫 Ct of the sample was lower than the 𝚫 Ct wt,min . According to this threshold, the positive control was positive in 60 (85%) of 71 runs, with a mean 𝚫 Ct value of 14.35 ± 0.73. All PNA clamp PCR reactions were prepared by the same person (S.O.), blinded for histopathological patient data.

## Sequencing of PCR Products

DNAsequencing was performed as previously described. 23 In cases of low concentration of mutated DNA, PCR products enriched for mutation (by PNA addition) were used as template (13 cases).

## Statistics

Categorical data were compared by Fisher exact test. Continuous data (not normally distributed) were compared by the MannWhitney U test. Statistical tests were performed 2-sided and P < 0.05 were considered statistically significant. The sensitivity of SLN examination by a method of interest versus routine LN examination was defined as the number of patients with SLNs positive by the method of interest divided on the number of patients with metastases detected in any regional LN (both SLNs and non-SLNs) by routine histologic analysis. All computations were done with the R software package version 2.7.0 (available at: www.r-project.org).

## RESULTS

## SLN Mapping

Ex vivo sentinel lymph node mapping (SLNM) was performed on the resection specimens of 217 consecutive patients undergoing curative surgery for primary colon cancer (Fig. 1). Clinicopathological examination showed that 53 of these patients did not fulfill the inclusion criteria. Characteristics of the 164 included patients are shown in Table 1. At least one blue-stained LN was detected in 158 (96%) of the 164 patients included. The median number of SLNs per patient was 4 (range, 1-10). An early subset of these SLNMs has been described previously. 14

## Routine Histopathological Analysis of SLNs and Other Regional LNs

Routine HES staining of SLNs and other regional LNs revealed metastases in 47 (30%) of the 158 patients with successful SLNM. In 32 (68%) of these patients, metastases were

detected in the SLNs, whereas 15 (32%) had metastases detected only in non-SLNs. Accordingly, if the HES examination had been limited to the SLNs, the false negative rate compared with similar analysis of all retrieved regional LNs would have been 32% and the sensitivity 68%.

## Detection of K-ras Mutations in the Primary Tumors

We have previously developed a highly sensitive PNA clamp PCR assay for mutations in codon 12 and 13 of the K-ras gene, capable of detecting a 1:20,000 dilution of mutant DNA in wild-type DNA in a cell line system. 23 Using this method with the highest observed K-ras 𝚫𝚫 Ct value (defined in Materials and Methods) for normal DNA as a threshold for positivity, we analyzed DNA from the primary tumors of the patients with successful SLNM. K-ras mutations were found in the primary tumor of 67 (42%) of the 158 patients with successful SLNM. All mutations were confirmed by DNA sequencing (Table 2). We tested the clinicopathological parameters in Table 1 for association with K-ras mutation frequency. The only statistically significant relation found was a higher mutation frequency in tumors of high and moderate differentiation grade as compared with those of low grade ( P = 0.007).

## Detection of K-ras Mutations in the SLNs of Patients With Mutated Primary Tumor

The semi-quantitative K-ras mutation measure 𝚫𝚫 Ct for the 272 SLNs of the 67 patients with K-ras mutated primary tumor are shown in Figure 2. When analyzing the data on a per LN basis, 83 (31%) of the 272 SLNs were positive for K-ras mutations. Of the 272 SLNs, 17 (6%) had metastases detected by routine HES staining. Of these, 12 (71%) were positive for K-ras mutations in the other half of the SLN. The 𝚫𝚫 Ct values of the SLNs with metastases detected by routine histopathological analysis were significantly higher than the 𝚫𝚫 Ct values of the other SLNs ( P < 0.001) (Fig. 2).

When analyzing the data on a per patient basis, K-ras mutations were detected in at least one SLN from 35 (52%) of the 67

| Mutation                       | No. Patients (%)   |
|--------------------------------|--------------------|
| One mutation                   | One mutation       |
| Gly12Ala (GCT)                 | 4 (6)              |
| Gly12Asp (GAT)                 | 20 (30)            |
| Gly12Arg (CGT)                 | 2 (3)              |

FIGURE 2. Dot plot of K-ras 𝚫𝚫 Ct for all SLNs from patients with K-ras -mutations in the primary tumor. Data for SLNs with (HES + SLNs) and without (HES -SLNs) known metastases detected by HES staining are shown, as well as for repeated analyses of a negative control sample (Neg. controls). The long horizontal line denotes the threshold used to decide whether the SLNs were positive or negative for K-ras mutations. The short horizontal bars indicate the median values.

![Image](data:image/png;base64,)

patients with mutated primary tumor (Fig. 3). Among these 67 patients, 47 were LN negative and 20 were LN positive by routine histopathological examination. In the LN negative group, 21 (45%) patients had K-ras mutations detected in one or several SLNs, indicating the presence of occult tumor cells. In the LN positive group, 14 (70%) patients were positive for K-ras mutations in their SLNs. Thus, the sensitivity of the SLN K-ras mutation analysis in terms of identifying patients with any regional LN involvement, detected by routine histopathology, was 70%. Routine HESstaining, if limited to SLNs only, would have given a corresponding sensitivity of 65% (13/20). Only 3 (15%) of the LN positive patients had neither HES -nor K-ras -positive SLNs. Thus, when analyzing one-half of the SLNs for K-ras mutations and the other half by routine HES staining, the sensitivity compared with routine histopathological analysis of all regional LNs retrieved was 85%.

FIGURE 3. Dot plot showing the highest SLN K-ras 𝚫𝚫 Ct value of each patient in the whole group of patients and divided into those with LN metastasis detected by routine histologic analysis (N + ) or not (N0). The long horizontal line denotes the threshold used to decide whether the SLNs were positive or negative for K-ras mutations. The short horizontal bars indicate the median values.

## DISCUSSION

We used a sensitive PNA clamp PCR assay to detect K-ras mutations in the primary tumors of colon cancer patients. The K-ras mutation frequency (42%) found in the tumors of this study was comparable to what others have observed (30%-50%). 25-29 The 7 most frequent point mutations in codon 12 and 13 were all detected (Table 2), and the frequencies of the different mutations were similar to those previously reported. 25-29 These findings confirm the reliability of our PNA clamp PCR assay for K-ras mutations compared with other methods. We also detected 4 patients with 2 different mutations present in the same tumor. Varying frequencies of such double mutations have been reported previously, 27-29 possibly depending on the method of detection or on different patient selections.

SLNs identified ex vivo in the resection specimens from the mutation positive patients were examined for the presence of K-ras mutations by the same method. These mutations are tumor-specific and thus their detection in LNs was interpreted as the presence of tumor cells. The sensitivity of the SLN K-ras mutation analysis in terms of identifying patients with any regional LN involvement detected by routine histopathology ('gold standard') was only 70%. Thus, the analysis cannot replace the routine histopathological LN examination.

However, the presence of mutated K-ras in SLNs from 21 (45%) of the 47 otherwise LN negative patients suggest that the method may be used to identify patients with occult metastases to SLNs. This may be clinically relevant. The decisions concerning adjuvant therapy to N0 (stage II) colon cancer patients are challenging, based on a combination of clinicopathological risk factors. 6,8 In our study, the group of 21 (45%) patients that would have been 'upstaged' by the SLN K-ras mutation analysis did not differ from the remaining 26 patients in terms of risk factors such as numbers of LNs examined, T-stage or tumor differentiation (data not shown). This suggests that the SLN K-ras analysis may identify an independent risk factor. However, clinical follow-up is required to determine the prognostic effect.

We have previously searched for tumor cells in the same SLN material by RT-PCR quantification of CK20 and MUC2 mRNA ( 14 and results not shown). This strategy may suffer from the downregulation of these epithelial-specific markers in some of the

1090

|

poorly differentiated tumors. 14 K-ras mutations are not expected to have the same disadvantage since the mutations are supposed to be present in the descendants of tumor cells in which such a mutation has occurred. We found, however, K-ras mutations to be less frequent in the poorly differentiated tumors as compared with welland moderately differentiated tumors. A similar relationship has been found in larger patient cohorts as well. 28 Even the K-ras mutation approach to detect SLN metastases may thus be less applicable in patients with poorly differentiated tumors as compared with patients with well- and moderately differentiated tumors.

Nevertheless, we detected K-ras mutations in SLNs from 21 (45%) of the 47 N0 patients with K-ras mutated primary tumor. In 7 of these patients, quantitative RT-PCR of CK20 and MUC2 mRNA did not indicate LN metastasis (results not shown). Accordingly, the detection of K-ras mutations in SLNs may be complementary to our mRNA strategy, despite the reduced occurrence in low grade tumors. The differentiation grades of 6 of these tumors were moderate, whereas one of them was poorly differentiated. In contrast, quantification of CK20 and MUC2 mRNA provided evidence of occult tumor cells in the SLNs from 16 (62%) of the 26 N0 patients who were negative for K-ras mutations (results not shown). The total number of N0 patients with CK20 or MUC2 positive SLNs was 31 (66%), compared with 21 (45%) for K-ras mutation detection. This indicated that the K-ras mutation detection might have lower sensitivity for tumor cells than CK20 and MUC2 mRNA quantification. However, clinical follow-up is required to determine which markers are prognostically most informative and to what extent they supplement each other.

We have previously shown that our PNA clamp PCR assay is able to detect K-ras mutations in a 20,000 times excess of wild-type DNA. 23 In this study a 1:1000 mutant:wild-type positive control scores negatively in 15% of the runs, indicating a lower sensitivity. This is partly due to the rather large inter-run variation of the negative control sample ( 𝚫 Ct standard deviation = 1.5), which led us to define a conservative threshold for positivity based on the lowest observed 𝚫 Ct value of the negative control. By this approach we avoided false positives at the expense of a lower sensitivity (false negatives).

Histopathological analysis and molecular methods were applied to 2 different halves of the SLNs identified in this study. Thus, small metastases that may be present only in one-half of the SLN may explain at least some of the nodes showing discrepancy between the molecular analyses and routine histology. The significance of the bisection on the probability of detecting metastases in both halves of the LNs should be addressed quantitatively by mathematical modeling.

We have previously shown that there is a linear relationship between the PNA clamp PCR measure ( 𝚫𝚫 Ct), and the relative amount of mutated DNA in the sample analyzed. 23 Thus, the 𝚫𝚫 Ct value may reflect the size of the metastases. In accordance with this, we observed higher 𝚫𝚫 Ct values for the SLNs with HES-detected metastases as compared with the other SLNs. Clinical follow-up of the patients may reveal to what extent different levels of 𝚫𝚫 Ct in SLNs give prognostic information.

Within the group of colon cancer patients with K-ras mutations, we have shown that sensitive detection of such mutations in SLNs may identify a group of stage I and II patients with molecularly detectable SLN metastases. The clinical importance of small metastases to SLNs in colon cancer is controversial. In the sixth edition of the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 'tumor clusters' with diameter < 0.2 mm are considered isolated tumor cells and not metastases. 1 Clinical follow-up is needed to clarify whether evidence of occult tumor cells generated by molecular methods like K-ras mutation detection has a prognostic value. The semi-quanti-

tative nature of the analysis may help to identify clinically relevant levels of metastases. If a prognostic value is demonstrated, SLN K-ras mutations may add to the repertoire of markers to predict outcome and guide therapy, in particular in stage II disease.
